body:
```
> foo = %%timeit -n 10 -r 1 -o time.sleep(1)
> res = 1 + 2
```

You're not supposed to use a cell magic this way; so this is actually not running a cell magic, a cell magic can't be assigned; the `%%` have to be at the beginning of the line. What you are doing here is running the line magic `%timeit` on `sleep(1)`, as the line magic cannot have setup code. Then you are running `res = 1+2` outside of the timeit magic.

The easiest way to see that is to issue a `hist -t` after runnign your cell; it will show you the translated history : 
```
foo = get_ipython().run_line_magic('timeit', '-n 10 -r 1 time.sleep(1)')
res = 1+1
```
Instead of the following you would expect: 
```
get_ipython().run_cell_magic('timeit', '-n 10 -r 1 -o time.sleep(1)', '1+1')
```
What you meat to do was:

```
In [12]: %%timeit -n 10 -r 1 -o time.sleep(1)
    ...: res = 1+1
784 ns ± 0 ns per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 1 run, 10 loops each)
Out[12]: <TimeitResult : 784 ns ± 0 ns per loop (mean ± std. dev. of 1 run, 10 loops each)>

In [13]: foo = _
```

The documentation should be more precise and we should try to catch %% in the middle of the line.

I see, thanks for the clarification (and for the hint to use `%hist -t`). So it seems that this is less an issue with iPython and rather a problem of my limited understanding of its functionality. Having said that, from the standpoint of "familiar" use of command options, I would assume that I can pass the name of the object directly to the cell magic for assignment, something like
```
%%timeit` -n 10 -r 1 -o foo time.sleep(1)
```
and analogously `%timeit -o bar time.sleep(1)` to the line magic.

But I guess you guys have considered that option and decided against it for some reason. So, maybe it would make sense to add an example for assignment using `-o` to the docs for both of the options? I guess that would avoid some confusion around the issue (and reduce the number of people opening github issues ;) ).

> @Carreau it seems like a bug that foo = %%timeit ... is allowed as a line magic. Do you think there's a reason for that, or is it just accidental?

No I don't think there is a reason; and that's mainly why I left this issue open. We should at least have a warning. 
We can have a look at `-o foo` as we are doing it in other magics. The issue here is that the option would differ between the cell and line magic.
